Award.AwardTitle: Listening into 2030: Imagineering the Future of Spoken Communication Science and Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advances in connected sensors, distributed computing, machine intelligence, and the cognitive neurosciences are likely to have a huge impact on speech communication and the hearing sciences. This workshop, taking place in Berkeley, CA on September 13-14, 2016, will provide a principled scientific and interdisciplinary foundation for research directions in the perceptual and cognitive sciences with applications to speech communication. It is intended that this workshop provide a road map for advancements in technology and therapeutics that may eliminate barriers to effective speech communication between humans and machines for a broad spectrum of the world's population.

The primary objective of the workshop is to explore a basis for a long-term research network that will enable communication among fields related to speech and hearing. It will bring together 40 researchers from a broad range of scientific and engineering disciplines associated with speech communication. Specific topics will include the possibility of techniques to bolster the listener's comprehension of auditory scenes and improve speech comprehension. Young researchers and researchers from groups underrepresented in science will be invited to participate. The workshop is co-funded by the Perception, Action, and Cognition Program in SBE directorate and the Robust Intelligence Program in CISE directorate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the workshop, which took place in Berkeley, CA in the autumn of 2016, was to envision how humans 15 years hence might connect with each other through speech and hearing. The notion was that such visions of the future would guide the research pathways in the perceptual and cognitive sciences with the greatest promise for exploiting the remarkable on-going advances in connected sensors, distributed computing, and machine intelligence that are transforming the modern world.

To accomplish the goal of the workshop to articulate an interdisciplinary research framework that will shape advances in fields related to speech and hearing, we brought together 40 researchers from a range of scientific and engineering disciplines and from both academic and industry settings. Discussions by this cohort were seeded with two types of input. One was a series of lectures by experts about the development of and implications of their own fields of expertise. The second was the results of using a product design technique, commonly known as Design Thinking, in small groups of 5-6 individuals. Here, articulating the real-life needs of a hypothetical user of speech and hearing communication technologies and therapies in 2030 guided the proposed solutions for addressing such problems.

The use of the above techniques and group discussion led to the distillation of several research programs that should shape human communication in 2030 through speech and hearing. These research programs spanned a range, from technically oriented ones focused on making hearing augmentation (such as hearing aids) more effective, to those focused on health and wellness especially in hearing impairment, to others on understanding the psychological and sociological elements of human communication mediated by technology.

These research themes should be productive areas for funding and investigation that will help address the listening and communication needs of a diverse cross-section of the population into 2030. Progress in these areas has the potential to have a large impact given the importance of hearing in spoken communication, social interaction, and artistic and aesthetic experience for humans.
